subdebateinfo.title: Transport and Regional Services: Transcription Services

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 31 July 2006:

quote.para: Can details are provided of costs associated with the transcription of communications, including ministerial media conferences for the financial years 2003-04 to 2006-07, by year, by department and agency in the Minister’s portfolio.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Senator Ian Campbell

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

entry.para: Department of Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 7 August 2006:

quote.para: With reference to the statement at page 76 in the Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) report on the loss of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs vessel the Malu Sara in October 2005, that: ‘The Australian Maritime Safety Authority’s Rescue Coordination Centre is based in Canberra. It is staffed by officers with marine or aviation backgrounds. In marine emergencies necessitating a SAR response in coastal waters, the local police undertake the initial response coordination. The RCC provide search advice based on analysis of wind drift, currents and tidal flows, EPIRB positions and when requested coordinate search craft, usually aircraft’:

item.para: What is the basis of this claim.

Does the National Search and Rescue Manual provide, in relation to the responsible rescue coordination centre, that ‘the first agency to become aware of a distress situation is obliged to respond until the appropriate SAR authority with overall coordination responsibility is in a position to assume that responsibility. It is imperative that the appropriate SAR authority is notified as soon as possible’.

Is it the case that in relation to the Malu Sara the first agency to become aware of the distress situation was the Queensland Police and that the appropriate search and rescue authority with overall coordination responsibility was AusSAR (Australian Search and Rescue).

How is the claim in the ATSB report that ‘in marine emergencies necessitating a SAR response in coastal waters, the local police undertake the initial response coordination and the RCC provide search advice based on analysis of wind drift, currents and tidal flows, EPIRB positions and when requested coordinate search craft, usually aircraft’ consistent with the relevant National Search and Rescue Manual protocol.

Did the ATSB receive a briefing on the National Search and Rescue Manual during the investigation of the loss of the Malu Sara and the preparation of its transport safety report; if so, who provided that briefing; if no briefing was received, why not.

Was the ATSB’s conclusions in relation to the coordination of the search for the Malu Sara, including its endorsement of AusSAR’s performance, informed by the National Search and Rescue Manual: (a) if so: (i) why does the ATSB report not make reference to the National Search and Rescue Manual, and (ii) why are findings in the ATSB report inconsistent with material provisions of the National Search and Rescue Manual; and (b) if not, why not.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Senator Ian Campbell

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.para: The ATSB report describes the cooperative nature of the relationship between the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) and State police services in relation to the provision of search and rescue services. It is a general description intended by the ATSB to place the discussion which follows into context. The text cited was reviewed by AMSA and the Queensland Police Service in draft form and no amendments were suggested.
Yes.

The Queensland Police Service was the first agency to become aware of the search and rescue incident involving Malu Sara and was best placed to respond to the vessel in the early stages. When it was clear that the search needed to be scaled up, coordination of the aerial search was passed to AusSAR (Australian Search and Rescue within AMSA) at 1215 on 15 October 2005. Coordination of the surface vessel search was passed to AusSAR as well at 1930 the same day.

See (1). This description was not intended to detail the contents of the National Search and Rescue Manual in relation to the respective roles of the Australian Government and the State/Territory Governments in relation to search and rescue responsibilities.
No. The ATSB was already aware of the National Search and Rescue Manual.

Yes. (a) (i) The ATSB report seeks to explain the most significant aspects of what happened and to recommend and encourage relevant safety action. The conclusion that the decisions made during the search and rescue operation by both the Queensland Police Service mission coordinator and AusSAR/AMSA were sound, was based on an assessment of the information available to these authorities at various times throughout the operation and what was reasonable in the circumstances. The question of whether or not overall coordination of the SAR operation should have been assumed by AMSA in the early stages of the operation was considered in that context. It was considered reasonable by the ATSB that the very experienced Queensland Police Service mission coordinator based on Thursday Island, with the benefit of local knowledge, was best placed to make decisions in relation to the SAR operation, in the early stages, given the way in which the situation unfolded. (ii) The ATSB does not believe the findings are inconsistent with the National Search and Rescue Manual. (b) See answer to previous questions.
